block.p: LOWER MANHATTAN The Ferry Experience: A Commuter's Video

Ed Davin has lived on Staten Island since 1966 and has spent 20 years commuting on the Staten Island Ferry. His video, ''The Ferry in Light and Shadow,'' includes 131 black and white photographs illustrating the ferry experience. The 21-minute tape is currently being shown in the Whitehall Ferry Terminal.

Mr. Davin's images focus on the changing weather and resulting patterns of light and shade that ferry riders experience. The photographs also offer glimpses of the Statue of Liberty, the city skyline and the docking machinery.
LOWER MANHATTAN The Ferry Experience: A Commuter's Video

Ed Davin has lived on Staten Island since 1966 and has spent 20 years commuting on the Staten Island Ferry. His video, ''The Ferry in Light and Shadow,'' includes 131 black and white photographs illustrating the ferry experience. The 21-minute tape is currently being shown in the Whitehall Ferry Terminal.

Mr. Davin's images focus on the changing weather and resulting patterns of light and shade that ferry riders experience. The photographs also offer glimpses of the Statue of Liberty, the city skyline and the docking machinery.

Seven of the photos are on exhibit nearby in the Bowling Green subway station (on the mezzanine level, outside the turnstiles). The exhibit consists of seven horizontal light boxes that each contain one black and white transparency of the photographs.

''The Ferry in Light and Shadow,'' video screening at Visit Center of the Council on the Arts and Humanities of Staten Island in Whitehall Terminal in Manhattan, open Thursday and Friday, noon to 6 p.m. and Saturday and Sunday 10:30 a.m. to 4 p.m.; free; (718) 447-3329; photograph exhibit in the Bowling Green subway station, mezzanine level; through December; free; (212) 878-7000.
SOHO A Japanese Artist Fulfills a Dream

''Asayan,'' a Japanese television program, gives viewers with artistic aspirations a chance to fulfill their dreams. Hidekichi Shigemoto, a Japanese artist and a recent winner on ''Asayan,'' dreamed of coming to New York to show his work.
Mr. Shigemoto's art, including the piece shown at left, will be on display in the Apartment, a gallery space in SoHo, through Oct. 30.

His work is painted on traditional scrolls and screens, and has been taken up by Nike, which recently commissioned him to create T-shirt designs. While Mr. Shigemoto is in New York, he plans to volunteer to paint walls in public spaces.

Hidekichi Shigemoto, art exhibit; Thursday through Oct. 30, Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m., Saturdays and Sundays 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; the Apartment, 101 Crosby Street, between Prince and Spring Streets; free; (212) 219-3661.
CHELSEA New Works At the Ice Theater
New works will be presented this week as the Ice Theater of New York performs at the Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers.

Ann Carlson's piece ''Angel: Part Two'' is one of those pieces, choreographed specifically for the ensemble, which was founded in 1984. (Doug Webster and Susan Pereira, shown at right, are rehearsing ''Angel: Part Two.'') A new work choreographed by Elisa Monte explores the visual appeal of artistic skating and the relationship of the body and the ice.
The Ice Theater ensemble will also perform repertory pieces by Peter Di Falco (''Tango Images'') and Doug Webster (''Transitions,'' a tribute to skaters who have died of AIDS).
Ice Theater of New York, Tuesday through Thursday at 7 p.m.; Sky Rink at Chelsea Piers, Pier 61, 23rd Street and the Hudson River; $20; (212) 929-5811.
ALSO AROUND TOWN

NORMA JEAN IN THE CITY -- You can discover ''Marilyn Monroe's Manhattan'' on a walking tour by Adventure on a Shoestring. Stops include her former apartment, the Sutton Place building where ''How to Marry a Millionaire'' was filmed and the site of the ''Some Like It Hot'' skirt-blowing scene, today, 3 p.m.; meet at northeast corner of 57th Street and First Avenue; $5; (212) 265-2663.

GOING, GOWANUS, GONE: -- Selected entries from ''Beyond the Gowanus Expressway,'' a competition seeking ideas for Sunset Park in Brooklyn if the expressway were demolished, will be on display and a forum will be held; forum Tuesday, 6:30 p.m., exhibit through Oct. 27, Monday through Friday, noon to 6 p.m.; Van Alen Institute, sixth floor, 30 West 22nd Street, near Fifth Avenues; free; (212) 924-7000, extension 16.

RECITAL AND RESPONSES -- Albert Tiu will perform a solo piano concert of works by Franck, Schumann and Rachmaninoff and will answer questions afterward; Recital Hall, Center for the Arts at the College of Staten Island, 2800 Victory Boulevard, off Staten Island Expressway; Saturday 8 p.m.; $15; (718) 982-2787.
